But her encounters with the spiritualist Selina Dawes, convicted of fraud and assault, turn into something more, dot dot dot. This is Sarah Waters so of course we have the two vital elements: lesbianism and Victorianism. She writes beautifully and atmospherically, although I think this suffers from being all in first person - she's not too good at differentiating voices, and it's so limiting in terms of what she tries to achieve in plot and suspense. I enjoyed this mostly until the final sections, partly because the plot becomes rather contrived, and partly because it's so depressing.
B0001KZM3O|4.0|Roger Waters had basically taken over the band at this point.  It was pretty much his band after the release of \\"The Wall\\", and he continued with \\"The Final Cut\\".<br /><br />I always try to think about the person who is genuinely considering whether or not to buy the product.  I write reviews for that person, not for the superfan who might be trolling the reviews looking to pick a fight over some under- or over-appreciated album.<br /><br />If you've heard and enjoyed \\"The Wall\\", then you will probably enjoy this album.  Basically, this album is akin to the more subdued moments in \\"The Wall\\".  It is a concept album about World War 2, with some light touches on the minor wars in between.  (Afghanistan and Lebanon are mentioned, but the album seems blissfully unaware of Vietnam... and that's just as well, since the British went through their war of disillusionment back in 1916 and so Vietnam isn't of much interest to them.)<br /><br />Musically, this album is off the tail-end of Pink Floyd's \\"stadium rock\\" period, to whatever extent that really existed in the first place.  It is slow-paced, subtle but rewarding.  \\"The Wall\\" was half-rooted in Pink Floyd's past, in the proggish rock of \\"Animals\\" and \\"Wish You Were Here\\".  That half is completely stripped away in \\"The Final Cut\\", and only the moody reflective elements are left.  Track-by-track, it would fail because no single moment has much impact.  As a whole, it succeeds as greater than the sum of its parts.<br /><br />Roger Waters departed the band after this album, and they were never quite the same again (though perhaps the remaining bandmates had the last laugh, since they produced two commercially successful albums, one of which was musically decent, while Waters produced two or three albums full of pretentious experimental crap that would make even Syd Barrett cringe.)  This is a good album, despite its flaws and dissimilarity to previous Pink Floyd releases.  Yet I would recommend that a fan with an incomplete collection hold off on purchasing this one until they had all the quintessential 70's Pink Floyd albums.complete collection hold off on purchasing this one until they had all the quintessential 70's Pink Floyd albums.

B00004XONN|3.0|This album comes complete with an awful lot of hype.  For the past half-decade, it's been lauded at various hip websites as the pinnacle of the band's career, the pinnacle of contemporary rock music, an experimental masterpiece.<br /><br />Alas, the album itself doesn't live up to the hype.  But don't take that the wrong way.  The album is still amazing in many respects.  The first track is gorgeous and better than anything Radiohead has ever done in other works.  But the rest of the album just doesn't quite come together to amount to anything.  It certainly isn't worth the praise heaped upon it.<br /><br />As always, I try to think of the people who might be led to see this review and consider buying the product.  Some of those people might be fans of Radiohead's earlier albums \\"The Bends\\" and \\"OK Computer\\".  \\"OK Computer\\" was among the five best albums made in the 90's, and certainly it embraced a more expansive view of music than the more conventional \\"The Bends\\".  But \\"Kid A\\" goes too far, it dives head-first into chaos and leaves pleasure and beauty behind.  Do not expect to like \\"Kid A\\" based on having enjoyed any previous Radiohead material.<br /><br />If it sounds like I'm giving \\"Kid A\\" a bad review, that's a mistake.  It's a good album... but not a great album.  The album's experiments miss as often as they hit.  But the great moments on this album are so worth hearing that they outweigh the drab and lifeless moments, if you have the patience.<br /><br />If you can grab it for under $10, I'd pick this up.  Otherwise, pass on it.

B00008H2LB|4.0|Now, before I write a review on this, I have to clear a few things up for people who aren't very open-minded at all. <br />Linkin Park is a blend of rock AND rap... no, it's not true rock, but I like it, so if you don't like hearing the mix of the two, then DON'T get this CD. It's that simple. Now, the stereotype that only wannabe goths listen to this music is ridiculous, I'm as preppy as they come. Their lyrics are very original, and relate to many things in real life. Now, these are my views...you don't have to believe them, but Linkin Park almost has its own genre of music, which some people happen to like. I may hate country and ska music, but people have a right to listen to them and they aren't \\"ruining\\" any other genres of music. So enough about this and more about the actual album, Meteora. <br /> <br />Meteora is Linkin Park's third album, if you count Reanimation, (which I do--an album is an album)and it is overall a very good compilation of songs, but in no way does it even come close to Hybrid Theory's success. There are some good songs on this album, and some of them sound like they were derived from songs on Hybrid Theory. (By the way... just because masses of people like a song, and if the song is considered 'mainstream' doesn't mean you have to immediately discard it as trash... I really don't understand that concept. If you like it, listen to it. If you don't, then don't listen to it!!!) <br /> <br />Let's go over the tracks on Meteora. <br /> <br />1)Foreword [3/10]: I gotta agree with most of you, there is no reason for this to be a seperate track. It's basically the beginning of the next track, 'Don't Stay'. It kind of kills the opening of the CD, to be honest. <br /> <br />2)Don't Stay [6.5/10]: This is a pretty good track, not really one of my favorites, but it's a decent song and Chester's vocals are loud and booming over the instrumentals. <br /> <br />3)Somewhere I Belong [8.5/10]: Some might say this was built to be just like 'In The End',but regardless, this in my opinion was one of the better tracks on Meteora. Shinoda's rhymes carry this song along with Bennington's very catchy chorus. <br /> <br />4)Lying From You [9/10]: This is a pretty heavy song, where the mix of Chester's angry-sounding vocals, heavy bass, and Mike's amazing rapping on this track makes it my favorite track on Meteora. I'm sure many don't agree on this, but it's my personal favorite. <br /> <br />5)Hit the Floor [6/10]: The instrumentals in this song really aren't that great, the vocals are good, but the background of this song just bores me, making it a sub-par track. <br /> <br />6)Easier to Run [6.5/10]: Okay, so maybe it sounds like Crawling. That's not factoring into my decision for this song. It has a much slower tempo than most of the songs on this album. Bennington's vocals are decent, but he kills Shinoda's rapping as he kind of raps and sings at the same time as Shinoda raps. If the tempo were sped up, and Chester would just stick to his own vocals, this would be a decent song. <br /> <br />7)Faint [7.5/10]: This is a good song because of the quickness and the beat. The instrumentals in the background hurry the song and make Chester's screaming fit in harminously with Shinoda's rap. <br /> <br />8)Figure.09 [8/10]: This is an extremely good track. Shinoda starts off rapping, and then it blends perfectly into Chester's vocals in the chorus. My favorite line here is \\"I took what I hated and made it a part of me.\\" <br /> <br />9)Breaking the Habit [7.5/10]: This is a catchy track that doesn't include Shinoda in it, and if I had to pick one track to not include him in, this would be it. Bennington has catchy lyrics with a great instrumental in the background. <br /> <br />10) From the Inside [5/10]: I really don't like this song very much. Chester just sounds like he's whining during most of Shinoda's rap, and during the vocals. The chorus is alright, but it doesn't make up for the rest of the song. <br /> <br />11) Nobody's Listening [7.5/10]: This track is a majority of Shinoda's rap. The Japanese flutes in the background really add that bit of spice to the track, and Bennington's lyrics in the chorus really make this a great song. <br /> <br />12) Session [7/10]: I don't know why everyone's saying this isn't music. It is, and it's a great instrumental--in my opinion, better than 'Cure for the Itch'. This is the kind of song they could play at sports games and stuff, it really pumps you up. <br /> <br />13) Numb [8/10] I definitely would agree that this is the best track to close out 'Meteora' with, Bennington dominates this track, but Shinoda makes the hook great with his lyrics \\"Caught in the undertow, just caught in the undertow\\" and the song ends on a great note, ending the CD on a great note as well. <br /> <br />So, to conclude, this CD was very good, but not as good as Hybrid Theory. As much as I love Linkin Park, I don't think they'll ever be able to make a CD as good as their first. <br /> <br />[AD] <br /> <br /> <br /> <br />

0385338686|5.0|I have liked almost all of author Sophie Kinsella's books, and THE UNDOMESTIC GODDESS is no exception. <br /> <br />Kinsella spins a good yarn, and the reason that her plots work this well is that she, herself, so thoroughly understands the settings into which she places her heroines. <br /> <br />There is a theme to Kinsella's novels, a theme which ultimately distills to an upper class young woman with everything going for her who unwittingly screws up her own life; the remainder of these works turn on the heroines' redemptions. <br /> <br />Still, it is the sharp observer's eye that Kinsella possesses, her clever imagination, and her keen (very keen) sense of humor that sets her fiction above the ordinary. This unusual and superior combination of elements have turned her novels into great--and deserved--successes. THE UNDOMESTIC GODDESS is no exception to the author's personal formula for excellence.
B00005NB8K|4.0|One of my favorite stories about Oliver Stone's \\"The Doors\\" comes secondhand, from a guy I know who saw the movie with a female acquaintaince.  About halfway through, she asked him, \\"What year did Jim Morrison die?\\", to which he replied, \\"1971.\\"   \\"And what year is it now?\\" \\"1968.\\"  She then sighed, a long and bored sigh. <br /> <br />\\"The Doors\\" is not easy viewing.  It is also not a strict biography of the band The Doors, because if it were, Frank Whaley and Kevin Dillon actually would have had something to do in the movie, rather than become perhaps the highest-paid extras in Hollywood history. <br /> <br />Once you understand these two joint concepts -- that Oliver Stone is making a movie about an idea rather than about a specific chain of actual events -- \\"The Doors\\" becomes essential viewing, not just the story of another band, but rather about a band that tried to break on through and redefine a generation's consciousness.  Until the lead singer burned himself out. <br /> <br />Jim Morrison quite clearly burrowed deeper into his own mind than most of us would care to go.  This trip, pardon the pun, unearthed song lyrics that were alternately of breathtaking clarity (\\"The Unknown Soldier\\") or revoltingly disjointed (\\"Not to Touch the Earth\\")... and that was on the same album.  By that same token, some scenes in \\"The Doors\\" are wonderful: the moment when Morrison composes the second verse of \\"Light My Fire\\" as an improv.  Other scenes go on forever and do nothing but make you loathe the man: the live performance of \\"Not to Touch the Earth\\"; any scene in which he asks a woman to \\"die for\\" him. <br /> <br />Where the DVD is occasionally hurt by the loss of subtitles (the dialogue in many scenes is unintelligible), Stone's director commentary is surprisingly spare and informative.  There's not much rambling here.  He explains which scenes were real, which were imagined (albeit based on real moments), which characters are composites. <br /> <br />I had no idea, before watching the DVD, that one of Stone's associates actually appears as Death, perhaps a dozen times, at first shortly after a direct quote from \\"The Seventh Seal\\", and then engaged in a progressive interplay with Morrison that climaxes at a birthday party late in the film.  Stone's commentary on Death's role in the movie plays a bit like a routine from \\"The Simpsons\\": \\"That's death!\\" \\"No, Grampa, that's Patricia Kennealy.\\" \\"That's death!\\" \\"No, Grampa, that's Nico.\\" \\"That's DEATH!\\" \\"No, Grampa, that's Patricia Kennealy again.\\" <br /> <br />Similarly, I knew that Floyd Red Crow Westerman played an Indian shaman supposedly transferred into Morrison's soul; I did not know that one scene in the movie shows him departing, clearly fed up with the increasing chaos. <br /> <br />This movie may never have worked without Val Kilmer.  It is impossible to tell where he ends and Morrison begins.  Kilmer seems to recognize that this movie is not a linear bio; even in scenes firmly rooted in historical fact (the meeting with Ray Manzarek on Venice Beach in 1965), Kilmer plays Morrison as stoned immaculate.  The sequence of Morrison's final poetry reading, split up as prologue and interludes throughout the movie, show Kilmer effortlessly playing the wise, drunken poet with prescient dialogue (\\"Enough to base a movie on?\\"). <br /> <br />The DVD advertises 43 minutes of \\"deleted scenes\\", though much of that is actually extended scenes, incorporating material already in the movie.  Kilmer's take on \\"Gloria\\" and particularly \\"The Unknown Soldier\\" would have added much to the texture of the movie had they not been deleted. <br /> <br />\\"The Doors\\" is now 15 years old, but still looks as if it were produced yesterday.  Kilmer's performance achieved the one thing that Morrison could not: immortality.
B00005JNZ4|4.0|Diane Lane is wonderful as Sarah Nolan, the preschool teacher whose family is convinced needs their help in escaping from the emotional wasteland which they see as the result of her recent divorce. In an effort to help Sarah find an interesting date which might blossom into real romance, her sisters Carol (Elizabeth Perkins) and Christine (Ali Hillis) conspire to post her somewhat embellished description which ends with the tag line \\"MUST LOVE DOGS\\" on an internet dating site. And while Sarah is at first mortified, she becomes intrigued enough to eventually search through the replies and arrange a blind date which initially reinforces her belief in the folly of the endeavor. However, she subsequently decides to make one more attempt, and meets Jake Anderson at the dog park. Jake is there because his friend has convinced him that he needs to stop wallowing in self-pity while repeatedly watching Dr. Zhivago in the belief that it will eventually end happily if he simply waits long enough. The moviegoer immediately senses the symmetry of their emotions, since Jake is also still recovering from his recent divorce and spends his time fashioning wonderful handcrafted wooden racing sculls whose details of master craftmanship are unappreciated by buyers who now want the convenience and speed of the new generation of fiberglass hulls. Of course, as in all romantic comedies, their initial conversation hits several speed bumps and Jake and Sarah and their borrowed (but beloved) dogs each head their separate ways. <br /> <br />They do subsequently decide that there was enough attraction to get together for dinner, and a truly hilarious although overblown scene regarding their lack of a condom ensues. (Yes, this movie has some adult moments despite the PG-13 rating and generally bland humor.) Their lives subsequently drift along, with Sarah being gently hit upon Bob Connor (Dermot Mulroney), the recently separated Dad of a very precocious student in her nursery school. After thatrelationship ends in disappointment (surprise, surprise, since you know Lane and Cusack share the biliing as the two co-stars), a furher obstacle gets in the way when Sarah encounters Jake on a date with a very good looking young woman who a friend has repeatedly implored him to meet. There is also an interrelated plot involving the internet dating habits of Sarah's recently widowed father Bill (Christopher Plummer) and several interested widows including Dolly (Stockard Channing). Of course, after several twists and turns and lots of funny moments, Sarah and Jake eventually reunite in a scene appropriately shared by their third co-star, the Newfoundland wonderfully named Mother Teresa. (No your eyes aren't deceiving you, if you stay for the outtakes which accompany the credits you will see that two slightly different looking dogs shared the work involved in stealing many of the scenes in which Mother Teresa was on camera.) <br /> <br />This movie is exactly what it is advertised to be. It is a lighthearted adult romantic comedy to simply be enjoyed in the knowledge that there will be many truly funny moments and that you will feel good when you leave the theater. (The audience when we attended laughed out loud frequently, not just smiled and chuckled.)  It doesn't have the star power of NOTTING HILL or the chemistry of Richard Gere and Julia Roberts in PRETTY WOMAN, but the performances of the leads are very good and the moviegoer soon thinks of them as Sarah and Jake, not Diane Lane and John Cusack. It also has the most memorable dogs in a romantic comedy since Bear and Bryant in the also critically panned but extremely enjoyable SWEET HOME ALABAMA. So, while strictly speaking there is no requirement that you MUST LOVE DOGS to enjoy this film, if you do you will certainly get an extra measure of enjoyment from it.  <br /> <br />Tucker Andersen <br />

Nevertheless, with the Religious Right backed by millions of dollars and millions of faithful followers, they easily continue lobbying their agenda to Washington. As it is now, it is also a very threatening situation when seven of the highest-ranking Republican senators receive a 100 percent scorecard from the right-wing organization, the Christian Coalition. <br /> <br />In his book, \\"The Most Dangerous Man in America?: Pat Robertson and the Rise of the Christian Coalition,\\" Robert Boston sheds much light on Robertson's theocratic rhetoric, which threatens the separation of church and state on many interrelated issues. Most absurdly, during an address to the American Center for Law and Justice in 1993, Robertson commented, \\"There is no such thing as separation of church and state in the Constitution. It is a lie of the Left and we are not going to take it anymore.\\"  <br /> <br />The author also makes known many of Robertson's sordid actions and claims, which include his ability to communicate with God directly, and the insensitive comments he made shortly after the Sept. 11 attacks that were also very similar to Jerry Falwell's. Unfortunately, President Bush has certainly done his part to please the Religious Right. For instance, many will never forget when he appointed extreme right-wing John Ashcroft as our country's attorney general.  <br /> <br />Regarding Ashcroft, in my letter-to-the-editor published in the San Antonio Current on Jan. 25, 2001, I said, \\"During his time in the Senate, John Ashcroft sponsored unconstitutional legislation violating the Bill of Rights. He is against the Fourth Amendment. He refused to protect abortion clinics from right-wing organizations. He praised Confederate soldiers for fighting to uphold slavery. He blocked the nomination of a gay man for an ambassadorship. He fought federal judgeship of an African American, and blocked efforts to bring an end to racial profiling.\\" <br /> <br />In the end, I just want a president who will fight for all civil rights (ethnicity, gender, sexual orientation and others), be liberal-progressive, have common sense and not cave in to corporate interests. But they will knock anything Chinese! They simply hate China for reasons they don't even understand. Americans foam in the mouth praising this film. But if sacrifice for the greater good is communist ideology, isn't it evil?    Hero is not completely historically accurate, but which Hollywood flick is?  Hero is simply a story well told, and told with astounding visual beauty.  It's great entertainment, and in that respect it's nearly perfect.    PS.  For those of you who can't speak Chinese, the English translation in this movie is reasonably good, although some emotion and power of the Chinese language is lost in the process.    Certain things simply sound lame when expressed in English (this goes both ways, of course).  However, there is a major mis-translation.  The two words written by Broken Sword actually means \\"all under heaven,\\" not \\"our land.\\"  Not even close.  But then, it's simply impossible to translate some things faithfully from Chinese into English, without making it sound tacky.

B0006IIPIK|5.0|With as much richness as this film holds, it is difficult to pick a point as to where to begin. I will preface this review with a bit of an understanding. This is a film that strongly divides people in terms of their temperament towards the film. I loved it. My appreciation of the style in which Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow was modeled after comes from a very long history. Also my love for technology and the various applications never cease to amaze me. With that having been said, let me go into some of the film's details. <br /> <br />Most remarkably, the retro futuristic feel of this film reminds the viewer of a visualization of radio sci-fi dramas of the 30s and 40s or perhaps a live action version of a graphic novel of the same era. The stereotypical characters are in full swing: the unassuming brainy assistant to the hero, the hero heartthrob and the headstrong and brassy yet vulnerable female reporter. The only slight deviation is the tough female protagonist and mysterious female villian. The colors in this film are so saturated and magnificent that you describe it to others as technicolor. <br /> <br />Acting in this film is quite impressive considering the amount of CG special effects that they had to anticipate and react with. Oscar winning performances perhaps not but spot on for the film genre. The actors chosen to play parts in the film were well chosen for their classic look that enhanced the ability to embody the characters.  <br /> <br />Make-up and wardrobe was also well done to coincide with the era and film continuity. Stylistic elements to transition from scene to scene are pretty amazing to. For example when flying from futuistic city to the mountains of Nepal, the plane flies over an illustrated map. Classic and stylish. There are also montages to advance the story that seem right out of the serials of the golden age. The dialogue also follows the formula with a few chuckles along the way. <br /> <br />I enjoy this film for its sci fiescapism. Many were skeptical of the production process used as it may signal a decline in things to come but I couldn't see that all films would be produced like this in the future. We may get snapshots every once and a while that take us on a retro futuristic journey but this film can stand side by side with a film that has live scenery.

From the smooth opening prelude by the Cora e Orchestra del Teatro alla Scala, under the direction of Claudio Abbado to the final Gloria all'Egitto, the cast and orchestra strike a prefect balance between voice and instrument in a performance that is spellbinding. It takes no time to warm up here, and the welcome is rich, indeed, as Placido Domingo eases us into the passion of Rademes early on in a truly spectacular Se Quel guerrier io fossi! The singing here from the entire cast is even and easy, and the delivery is balanced. Each singer is comfortably within his and her range and matched in temperament, and this matching is evident from song to song, and none more so than the trio Terzetto: Vieni, o diletta, apressati, sung by Elena Obraztsova (Amneris), Ricciarelli and Domingo. The tendancy to \\"shout\\" one's role can be a killer for singers and this reviewer has commented on that tendency in the past. There is none of that here, which is why this CD comes so strongly recommended. The quality of the CD remaster is superb and the accompanying booklet, while not as complete as I would have preferred - no introduction, no bios, no historical facts -- is adequate as far as it describes what is occurring during each song.

B000929AJQ|4.0|Nine Inch Nails has always been a top quality project, since it is hard to call NIN a band.  Trent Reznor has always experimented with different styles of music, from rap (\\"Down With It\\" off Pretty Hate Machine, released in 1989) to tear-eyed ballads (\\"Hurt\\" off The Downward Spiral, released in 1994) to strong metal (most of the Broken EP, released in 1992).  Let everyone just say that Nine Inch Nails has done it all.  Now in 2005, sixteen years after they released Pretty Hate Machine, Mr. Reznor and Company gives us \\"With Teeth\\", a combination of all of the previous Nine Inch Nails works. <br /> <br />The album fires off in a different way than the older works.  \\"All The Love In The World\\" starts from the get-go with Trent singing along to a nice line, which transforms to a piano in which people can dance to.  The album then goes heavy, with \\"You Know Who You Are\\", in which Trent yells out the chrous, with profanity, along Dave Grohl's upmost superb drummming. <br /> <br />\\"The Collector\\", which is the third track, explodes out with Mr. Grohl still drumming.  \\"The Collector\\" is not as good as some of the other songs on the album, but it is better than a large percent of modern rock.  \\"The Collector\\" then fades into the first single, and one of the catchiest songs on the album, \\"The Hand That Feeds\\".  \\"The Hand That Feeds\\" has a very catchy rhythm that fits in with Trent's singing.  The song can also be remixed by owners of Apple's \\"Garageband\\" program. <br /> <br />The fifth song, \\"Love Is Not Enough\\", is a drop in quality compaired to the songs that came before it.  This is the worst song on the album, but people will still like it.  \\"Love Is Not Enough\\" fades into one of the best songs released by Nine Inch Nails.  \\"Every Day Is Exactly The Same\\" is a complete 180 degree turn from the five songs that came before it.  Sing along with the chorus, it is the best part of the song.  The piano at the beginning catches the attention, then the drumming and Trent's singing keeps a hold on the listener for the entire song until the fade into the next track. <br /> <br />\\"With Teeth\\" is, obviously, the title track and a good one.  The only thing that gets annoying is the \\"With-a Teeth-a\\" part. <br /> <br />The next song, \\"Only\\", is a current single that has one of the most creative videos in the last few years.  The Eighties and Pretty Hate Machine returns in \\"Only\\" with spoken words until the chorus.  Listen good with this song and you will find a few surprises, such as the piano at the beginning.  \\"Getting Smaller\\" is a reminisce of today's rock, in short words, it is pretty bland.  \\"Sunspots\\" is a crown jewel in the album.  It reminds me of NIN's previous works. <br /> <br />The last three tracks all fades into each other and are some of the best of the album.  \\"The Line Begins To Blur\\" starts with a big drum line then completely goes the other direction.  This keeps on going with \\"Besides You In Time\\", which has some of the best singing by NIN.  That fades into the best song on the album, \\"Right Where It Belongs\\".  This saddening piece of art is \\"Hurt\\", only shorter and not as famous. <br /> <br />With Teeh, or without, this album is going to entertain fans until the next Nine Inch Nails album.
B00099BPP6|3.0|This is a 2005 2-CD release of a 1964 recording of Rigoletto, featuring the talents of Carlo Bergonzi, singing the role of the Duke, Renata Scotto singing Gilda and Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau singing Rigoletto. By now, anyone who owns this recording has formed his or her own opinion about the interpretation of the role of Gilda by Ms. Scotto. I found her voice almost too overwhelming and \\"earthy\\" for such a vulnerable character as Gilda, although she does hit some incredible highs in her Caro Nome and demonstrates a wonderfully smooth ability to glide into the higher scale with what appears to be effortless ease. Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau's voice on the other hand is saturated with emotion and in the manner of its delivery it evokes empathy for the character. Carlo Bergonzi, too, seems the right fit for the role. His voice contains just the right amount of arrogance and swagger that you would expect from the Duke. Alas, the only singer out of place, it seems, is Ms. Scotto, not because she is ill-equipped, but rather because her voice may lack the vulnerability and innocence of the character that is Gilda. Still, this is a fine 2-CD set -- and it pays to remember that one reviewer's opinion of one aspect of a recording does not make it so for all listeners. The orchestra, Coro e Orchestra del Teatro alla Scala, under the direction of Rafael Kubelik is flawless, as is the overall quality of this Deutsche Grammophon release. The booklet that comes with this set contains bare bones information limited to the order of songs and featured singers and not much else.
B000A59PMO|2.0|Veronica Mars, a teenager at a high school where the wealthy send their teens, is helping solve private investigations through her father's PI business (he's also the former Sheriff of the area.) They live in a fictitious town known as Neptune, California.<br /><br />On top of this, Veronica has to deal with the strife of her classmates (who are much better off than herself), the fact that she comes from a broken home (her mother left her father and her), and try to avoid the local turf wars in her corner of the world.<br /><br />Sounds like a winner, doesn't it?<br /><br />But there are several problems with the basic premise of this series that I just couldn't get my mind around.<br /><br />First (and DEFINITELY foremost) is that the children of millionaires DO NOT go to public schools. They go to private schools. Why would they mingle with the lower classes when they don't have to? The simple answer is that they never would.<br /><br />Secondly, there were a bunch of little things that could've been fixed but weren't. For instance, Veronica gets the headlights of her car bashed in by a rich punk. Then the next scene shows her driving down the street at night ...WITH THE HEADLIGHTS ON! Some might argue that she got them fixed, but let's remember that she and her father are not that well off.<br /><br />Thirdly, Sheriffs are not assigned to \\"towns\\"; they patrol and enforce the law in counties. And Neptune is a city/town. Little things like this shows me how poorly the script writers researched various aspects for the show. And these oversights easily seeped into almost all aspects of the series.<br /><br />And the one aspect of the show that I felt most curious and drawn to -- that being the father/daughter/mother relationship -- was never fully explored. Now I know that this will be a culminating factor in the series, but I felt that too much time was spent on Veronica's high school life and not enough on her home life. A better balance was definitely needed.<br /><br />For better series' look toward Wonderfalls or Dead Like Me.nitely needed. <br /> <br />For better series' look toward Wonderfalls or Dead Like Me.
0811826848|5.0|I love this book. But I have got two major bugbears with it. The first one is the way they whitewash over some of most interesting events - the break-up for example is nowhere near as prickly as some other books describe it. But to hear the Beatles talk about the events through their own eyes is great - even more so for Ringo and George, because their biographies weren't very detailed.  <br />The other problem I have with it is that it just focuses on the history - it hasn't even got a proper discography at the back. I would have enjoyed some reproductions of the covers, for example, and some information about chart placings. I would also have enjoyed some more quotes and memories from the other people involved. <br />But these are all minor points - I do love the book, and I thoroughly recommend it to everyone.

0670033375|4.0|Having read Guns by Mr. Diamond I had to read Collapse.  I like a lot of what Mr. Diamond said, but in making me think about the subject, I drew a different conclusion.  While societies of different times and places on earth prove the importance of taking care of the land, I got the conclusion that religion and or people's values screwed them up more than anything.  The folks at Easter Island, the ancient ones, even the christian Norse of Greenland all proved that reliance on religion can cause collapse just as well as ignorance of the land.   <br />While Mr. Diamond brought back a favorite read of mine in Malthus while examining Rowanda, he could of used Thorstein Veblen and The Theory of the Leisure class for the Easter island and Norse Greenlanders(that being the lack of big game to hunt, can lead to a reliance on religious icons even if it leads failure.)    <br />When Jared Diamond writes books he throws so much useful information into it.  But when the conclusions don't mesh with the theme of the book, one has to figure the value of the book.  Diamond was brilliant in many parts of the book, and the fact that he doesn't try to explain religion's role in Collapse only gives me a sense that this very smart man wants to stay away from an agruement that's not worth his time.  Read the book, it's more than worth the price on the dust jacket.
B00005JNJT|5.0|Why? Lots of reasons. For one, it's got Christian Bale in the lead role, Michael Caine as the strongest Alfred ever, Rutger Hauer as a Donald Trump lookalike, Morgan Freeman acting about like James Bond's Q, and a bunch of other good talent. That cast just won't let a movie go down the tubes.<br /><br />Except for Batman himself, this doesn't look like a comic book movie, and I mean that in the best way possible. It opens on a grey and gritty prison, then turns into a Himalayan trek, then flirts with Ninja stuff before returning to Gotham. The fight scenes are good, but oddly indistinct. It's not always clear who's doing what to whom, but that's even more effective than standard fight choreography - it reinforces the sense of Batman swooping in unseen on the bad guys, taking them down before they know they've been hit.<br /><br />And Gotham City is good, too. It appears in earlier and later times, with a clear display of decay in between. It's a good vision: tall, sweeping Art Deco lines, especially in that monorail. Other parts looked like Cubist landscapes, in their organic sprawl. The Plot Device was a disappointment. I won't give it away, but when you see it, think: people are mostly water, too.<br /><br />This one's really good, even if you don't usually like comic book movies. It's got good, varied action, and good characters, or good enough. In a summer of good summer movies, this is about the best so far. Enjoy!<br /><br />//wiredweird

B000001ESP|5.0|This is definitely a classic in rock and roll. Rush tones down the progressive side of their music for shorter, catchier tunes but remain just as good. Also one will notice that there are a few more synths than on previous albums. If you hate synths then this is bad news but i feel they help enhance the album. I am sure everyone who listens to classic rock radio knows Tom Sawyer,Limelight,and Red Barchetta. Red Barchetta is a personal favorite because of the intro. It consists of soft guitar sounds and you can practically feel a cool breeze running through your hair in the morning. Witch Hunt is also good, very dark for a Rush song. The synth sound are particularly creepy. And the closer Vital Signs rules it is very reggae-ish. Fans of the Police may want to check this song out. <br /> <br />And then of course there is The Camera Eye. Eleven minutes of musical genius in my opinion. Probably the last progressive song Rush ever did. Cool synth intro (remember it is 1981) that soon explodes into a nice rocker. And how can we forget the instrumental YYZ? One of the most well-known instrumentals in classic rock? Maybe... <br /> <br />Definitely a must-own for fans of Rush and classic rock.
0679720200|2.0|This is one of those books that you come across in your life that people talk about and mention to you a few times and eventually you get around to reading it.  Since it's only about 123 pages long, it is definitely a quick read.  The storyline goes at a good pace and there's just enough happening to keep you interested in the plot.<br /><br />Most people I've talked to about this book didn't care for the lack of details.  That didn't bother me so much.  The only reason that I am not giving this book a better review is because of my frustration with the main character.  If Mersault would just CARE about something, anything, the outcome of this story would be so much different.  Sure, this is the point the author is trying to get across, but still.  I found Mersault's stand-offish attitude to be very frustrating.<br /><br />This is definitely one of those books that you want to discuss with a friend when you are finished, so be sure that if you grab this book, grab another copy for a friend as well.

B0009A1AS2|5.0|I have seen enough. How many of you have been DT fans since 1991? I HAVE. The band took the world upon it's shoulders- literally- to bear the weight as the Greatest Rock Band on Earth. EVERY SINGLE album sans \\"Live: AT Budokan\\", has been a piece apart, clever, precise, eccentric, bombastic, revolutionary, outrageous, spontaneous, and with a tad of humor and utterly amazing self-indulgence. DT is SO smart, they are FULLY aware they are pulling everyone's string, except for the most \\"devoted\\", who REALLY look for the magic pearl in every priceless melody. <br /> John Petrucci pretty well says it all in the final lyrics on this amazing project: \\"The story ends where it began...\\", and sure enough, and only one other reviewer even seemed to notice- \\"Octavarium\\" reprised the beginning of \\"The root of all Evil.\\" In addition, \\"The root of all Evil\\" climaxes with passages directly from the arrangement in \\"Octavarium.\\" DT is so intelligent as a band, they love to tease, and if you listened instead of \\"expecting\\"...you would fine little gemstones of absolute magic throughout this magnificent Magnum Opus. <br /> John Petrucci's guitar work is stunning. Some of his finest work on chord progression and tones I have never heard from his instrument. John Myung- what can I say- every album he is a genius. Jordan Rudess actually pulls out some solos more reminicent of Wakeman/Emerson, but just ever-so-slightly. Mike Portnoy is the biggest surpise of all! Laying low, it's almost like he is using brushes on parts of \\"Octavarium\\", with perfect timing on that massive drum package!!! For Mike to \\"tame his shrewd\\", is just absolutely necessary on this project. <br /> The vocals of James LaBrie are not \\"stellar\\" because his \\"pipes\\" aren't really the \\"fifth\\" instrument here, except on the title track and \\"Root of all Evil.\\" Basically, he is just calm and relaxed. Again, for the album itself, it was necessary. <br /> I am sick of all the comparisons. Although DT has NEVER hidden their influences, people keep comparing, yet no one on the PLANET can come close to this musical machine. I have never seen such a mass of pathetic reviews mixed in with thoughtful and intelligent reviews in my life! I don't mind negative reviews, but save it for the bands you are comparing DT to. Don't insult this band nor it's core of REAL fans who live by their sound and vision. <br /> \\"Octavarium\\" is a monsterous and superb album. By the way, DT has done a 42- minute opus and a near 80- minute opus in addition to these 20- minute tunes we have heard. To them, 20 minutes is a piece of cake. Go buy the album. Put on the headset. LISTEN. Be amazed.

B0002OERI0|5.0|Green Day has been undeniably one of the greatest and most popular bands of the mid-90's, and now the 2000's.  The band has obviously matured as far as there music, as \\"American Idiot\\" has displayed in comparison with their previous albums.  It seems that their previous works were fun to listen and jam to, but American Idiot takes them and the listener to a whole new level.   <br /> <br />Complex and incredibly catchy melodies dominate this album, anyone who appreciates true rock music has to be a fan of the music written by the band on this cd.  I found it impossible to find a song I disliked, and it is seriously addicting.  Although Green Day's music has always been respectable, a brilliant mix of guitar and bass solos and obviously awesome drum patterns, \\"American Idiot\\" seems to be a \\"toned down\\" and perhaps classier version of their punk rock.  What comes out is almost a different Green Day style, complimented beautifully by what has become poetry from Billie Joe Armstrong.   <br /> <br />The themes, motifs, symbols and other poetic devices used in the lyrics, featuring the \\"Jesus of Suburbia\\" and \\"St. Jimmy\\", along with others, make them seem like your listening to crafted poetry, and like a lot of famous poets, some of the words are anarchical.  Overall, this is the greatest album from one of the most popular bands of our time.  This is truly Green Day's Master Piece.

B000002GQG|5.0|Like a gangbuster, I'm going to approach my review of Lost Chord by getting directly into the album tracks with my sleeves rolled up.  Yes, you know you're in for something more cosmic than Chord's predecessor, Days of Future Passed immediately with Graeme Edge's somewhat puzzling recitation of the poem Departure before it segues quite nicely into \\"Ride My See-Saw,\\" a song that seems to be a leftover from DOFP in content.  For years I have liked this great harmony heavy, catchy pop single, but now I see that the lyrics have very much in common with the working day theme from the previous album, and really understand it's meaning now more than I ever have:<br /><br />\\"Left school with a first class pass<br /><br />Started work but as second class<br /><br />School taught one and one is two<br /><br />But right now that answer just ain't true.\\"<br /><br />Yes, so much for that idyllic concept of graduating and experiencing the real world once you find out that landing the job of your dreams isn't going to be that easy.  In essence, we're all riding that see-saw and looking for a way off, someone else to take our place so we can find something better.<br /><br />\\"See-Saw\\" is followed up by Ray Thomas's \\"Dr. Livingstone, I Presume, which carries the concept of searching for something a bit further.  The song is one of Ray's typically playful, bouncy, and very British sounding compositions that deals with very successful careermen who, though they have had luck in their fields, are still unfulfilled.  \\"I've still not found what I'm looking for...We're all looking for someone.\\"  So on it goes.<br /><br />This is where we get into the eastern spirituality and exploration that inevitably put the Moodies into the unenviable position of musical gurus for people who didn't realize the band was asking as many questions as they were.  \\"House of Four Doors\\" is a spritual quest for inner peace, and as each door opens, you are supposed to get deeper into your personal \\"core.\\"  I'm not sure I have ever understood the Hindu philosophy of spirituality, but I definitely appreciate all the sophisticated musical passages each door creak involves, complete with that Beach Boys chorus so prominently displayed.  In the center of this piece sits the piece de resistance, \\"Legend of a Mind,\\" a somewhat whimsical ode to Timothy Leary, the man who gave us LSD.  I have always enjoyed this song, as I think it's singularly better than anything on the Beatles' Sgt. Pepper album, even if I don't condone the use of hallucinogenics.  This song is brilliant in every way, and the best thing about it is Ray Thomas's Native American sounding flute.<br /><br />This long concept song is followed up by Justin Hayward's gorgeous \\"Voices in the Sky,\\" in which he seems to be longing for the freedom of a singing bird or the innocence of children skipping rope in the middle of some sort of emotional bout he's experiencing.  Lovely and full of simple yearning, it's easy to see why this has long been a favorite among Moodies fans.<br /><br />Mike Pinder offers us a very Lennon-esque sounding \\"The Best Way to Travel\\" as we seem to be going back and forth between the DOFP concept and moving onto more of a spiritual hippie vibe.<br /><br />The Hayward/Lodge composition \\"Visions of Paradise\\" has rather nonsensical lyrics that sound like an acid trip, which is quite beautiful and (sorry) groovy, only made moreso by the enhancement of sitar from Justin and Ray Thomas's beautiful birdlike flute.  This is truly a tranquil and captivating piece of music.<br /><br />\\"The Actor\\" is another beautifully crafted ballad by Justin Hayward about hiding feelings of great loss for a broken love.  While it carries a similar feel of strong longing to \\"Nights in White Satin\\" it isn't quite as stirring as the former, but it still carries a lot of power.<br /><br />Graeme Edge then reveals in his poem \\"The Word\\" that the lost chord is called \\"Om,\\" the final track on the album.  This is unmistakably asong designed for transcendental meditation and, while a seemingly dated concept, the song is still hypnotic and captivating.  The harmonies are beautiful, and Justin Hayward's  quickly learned mastery of the sitar is to be highly commended.  Each time I play this album I love it more and more.  It is one of the best of the \\"core seven\\" albums, but I don't think it's a good idea to skip any of them.  As far as Lost Chord goes, however, I have only one word to describe it:  Heaven.esigned for transcendental meditation and, while a seemingly dated concept, the song is still hypnotic and captivating.  The harmonies are beautiful, and Justin Hayward's  quickly learned mastery of the sitar is to be highly commended.  Each time I play this album I love it more and more.  It is one of the best of the \\"core seven\\" albums, but I don't think it's a good idea to skip any of them.  As far as Lost Chord goes, however, I have only one word to describe it:  Heaven.      <br /> <br />
B00005JNSK|4.0|Willy's back, and of course with Depp and Burton things have changed.  Some for the better and some for the worse, as is often the case.  Oh, and to clarify now, the film is not actually that dark.    The plot itself feels a little awry.  For instance, Charlie is treated almost as a sub-character for much of the film, and we are pressed to pay more and more attention to the factory and Willy Wonka himself.  This is particularly true when Burton shows us the newer personal side of Wonka, filled with flashbacks and more.    On top of that the whole feel of the musical has diminished, but admittedly they're just not as popular anymore so no surprise.  Oh yes, the Oompaloompas sing, and in quite a  variety of styles too, but don't expect Depp to crack out a note, or the kids.    And speaking of Oompaloompas, in the previous versions where obviously a few characters played them, this version has one actor digitally cloned into all of the Oompaloompas.  Not only that, but he is not the most appealing Oompaloompa, as he actually fits the image of a man who I do not think should be around kids.  Oh yes, I definitely loved the musical numbers, and the shrewd comments based around them particularly by the kid characters, but still, scary man.    So did I like it?  Yeah, I did, and although I prefer Gene Wilder's version this one gives us another side, perhaps unnecessary side, to this strange yet classic tale of a poor boy and his fortunate and strange trip to the Wonka Chocolate factory.

Why 4.5 stars? While I enjoyed the autobiographical aspects, many were out of place in a book about writing. I did enjoy the glimpses into Mr. King's life, believe me, but they were unexpected and interfered somewhat with the hunger I had for the knowledge he was sharing.<br /><br />Having read this book after not being a Stephen King reader, I can say without a doubt I would enjoy reading his full autobiography. I just wish it hadn't been included in \\"On Writing.\\"<br /><br />Stephen King has a lot of real world experience, and I find myself re-reading the portions of the book having to do with writing style and editing, and wishing there was less biography. A must have for writers at any level, an inspiration even if you aren't a King fan, and a nice semi-autobiography for fans who are not interested in the craft of writing.
